item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Niall:

say you have 46% voting for party a, 44% voting for party b and 10% voting for 3rd parties, you have 54% of people voting AGAINST party a but party a still gets in

In Canada this isn’t really a bad thing. It means that 54% voted for the opposition, or in other words, have given the opposition more power than the elected party.

Say for fun(this never happened), conservatives get 40%, liberals 30%, ndp 30%. Obviously the cons win but in the house of commons they only have 40% of the seats. Now say Cons make up this crazy extremist bill that everyone else is against, the libs and ndp could stop it because they have 60% of the seats and voting power.

The problem (if it is a problem?) is when the cons get 51%. Than they have the power to do as they wish, with 49% people unhappy. The opposition is totally powerless.
